newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil shares end modestly higher in quiet session.
newsitem.headline: Brazil shares end modestly higher in quiet session.

text.p: Brazilian shares ended modestly higher Thursday after paring earlier gains in another session marked by lackluster activity, brokers said.
The Sao Paulo bourse's Bovespa index .BVSP closed up 0.52 percent at 63,910 points. Volume was a moderate 306.4 million reais ($300.2 million).
The Senate approval of a bill exempting exports from a tax levied by state governments failed to push stocks -- even those of export companies -- much higher, traders said.
Share prices had already reflected the positive effects of the elimination of the so-called ICMS tax on exports of primary and semi-manufactured goods, traders said.
Mining conglomerate Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, and steel firm CSN posted small gains. Analysts said the two companies would benefit most from the measure.
Vale preferred rose 0.71 percent, closing at 21.20 reais, while CSN stock gained 0.44 percent to 22.85 reais.
Food processor Ceval, also named by analysts as a company that would benefit from the tax exemption, which climbed 1.51 percent to 8.02 reais.
Some traders said concerns over the so-called CPMF cheque tax weighed on the market Thursday.
On Wednesday, the Chamber of Deputies approved regulatory details of the CPMF tax, a 0.2 percent levy on all financial transactions. It is intended to fund health services.
The bill was sent to the Senate, which might vote on the matter later Thursday.
Benchmark Telebras rose by a modest 0.51 percent, closing at 78.40 reais.
Sao Paulo bourse's power sector index (IEE), comprising the nine most liquid stocks of the sector, rose 0.39 percent.
Analysts said they expected Friday's session to be marked by reduced volume and some profit-taking.
